Most of the people currently still claiming that "Bitcoin can't work" operate on the premise that centralization is important and desirable. Once Bitcoin is mature, these people will inevitably clamor for a central bank of bitcoin. Imo this will become a huge public debate.
Are you assuming governments would never want to get involved in bitcoin banking?

Why imo a "federal reserve bank of bitcoin" is undesirable: - Systemic risk: the "Bitcoin Fed" could be hacked or face a bank run - Private profits, socialized risk would cause bureaucratization - Bitcoin banknotes would only be fractionally backed, at expense of savers

The lack of centralization in bitcoin will further be improved by multi-sig solutions, known as "smart custody" and "collaborative custody". This is why bitcoin is so desirable as a hedging instrument: it can insure traditional portfolios against trust based, systemic risks.

Bitcoin exchanges & custodians are "too big to bail", i.e. they can fail like pre 1914 gold banks could: - No lender of last resort - Private insurance only option - Ultimately good for HODLers: no socialization of risk - But: due diligence matters, buyer beware

it's not a SHA2 problem, it's a serialisation problem. most hash functions as building blocks have the same chunk design. HMAC-SHA2 for example shows how you fix base hashing block artefacts with hardening serialisation. Bitcoin serialisation should have done analogous.

similarly the difficulty adjustment was in multiples of 2 only, which is easy to make more finely adjustable, but again decided not to as it's simpler to code and verify and does not matter for stamp applications. but for bitcoin both of these things matter.
that's a problem with Bitcoin's hashcash serialisation, not SHA2. you see analogous flaws eg length extension attacks on badly designed roll-your-own crypto HMAC-SHA2 variants.

in principle that would have made sense, if there was clean way to disable both overt and covert. but now there are 5% of deployed miners that can do overt asicBoost only. it is a design flaw in Bitcoin's hashcash serialisation, so fixing it long term seems like a good idea to me

there are 29 bits for parallel soft-forks, after https://lists.linuxfoundation.org/pipermail/bitcoin-dev/2018-March/015801.html there remain 13. bitcoin has never done a parallel soft-fork. so 13 is plenty IMO, ie they were useless, unused bits anyway. reserving them per bip 320 avoids warnings and avoids interfering with BIP8/9.

also I don't think "exploit" is a useful distinction. we know ASICs have to use the most efficient PoW algorithm. yes AB short-cut is a crypto design defect in Bitcoin's hashcash serialisation, but it is not trivial to fix now. i think it would be interesting to plan ahead to fix

The key indicator for the start of a sustainable bull run is likely a decoupling of asset values from Bitcoin (i.e. Bitcoin’s strength weakens other networks or vice versa). Anything else is just speculation again (maybe we need another bubble to learn more lessons? )...

So, even if the Bitcoin network effect or store of value hypothesis results in an increased price, this currently translates into broader market based upon sentiment, not fundamentals. So in practice, other cryptos get a boost from any improvements in Bitcoin fundamentals today.

It’s easy to argue that Bitcoin can be worth $10k or $20k, or even $100k, but the problem is that as the price has been rising towards those levels, we’re not seeing Bitcoin dominance increase disproportionately.

This means that as the Bitcoin price rises, so does the price of other crypto’s, irrespective of value. This is a key point - Bitcoin could double overnight, but does this mean other assets should too, even if nothing has changed on their end in term of development, network etc?

I should say “cannot *easily* be seized by the state.” It can be stolen if people manage to physically grab you or get into your computer & get your private keys. But Bitcoin can’t be programmatically seized or frozen at network level. Can’t be inflated, can’t be counterfeited.

Bitcoin’s fundamental value proposition is seizure resistance. It is property as cryptography, a form of wealth that cannot be seized by the state. It protects against inflation scenarios like Venezuela and Weimar, and seizure scenarios like the Russian and Cuban revolutions.

It's psychological for investors. If gold has a 6000 year history of being worth something, chances are next year it'll still be around so people will park value in it. If say Bitcoin was only 1 day old but technically sound, would you park say 10% of your net worth in it?

We can measure all the fundamentals; TPS, cost of attack, on-chain value flows, mining hash rates, decentralisation of contributors, etc... in the end, they all point to its capabilities of longevity. What may kill Bitcoin is something unexpected and not currently being measured.

"Product-market fit" is a startup industry term. It becomes awkward when applied to Bitcoin. This is because Bitcoin is not a product, it's a DIGITAL COMMONS. A collective resource under common ownership which we collectively develop for mutual benefit.
